number of helpful: 21 of 24 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								First Steam review here, so go easy on me please!I had been following Stonehearth since its Kickstarter campaign back in 2013, and I finally bit the bullet back in August.  Since then I have enjoyed (almost) every minute of gameplay.  As many reviewers have noted, this is really a niche game, and if you are into a slow-paced city building sim with some RPG and RTS stuff mixed in, this is the game for you.  For me, I love setting up my little town so that it is self-sustaining, and then sitting back and watching.  Seeing the little Hearthlings running around, farming, shepherding, and cooking, all the while getting hungry and eating, and eventually relaxing by the fire and sleeping, it is really quite pretty to see.  Let me detail some pros and cons as I see it:Pros:+Voxel Based graphical style+Custom Buidling Designer+City Building and strategy combined+Playable! (can't say this for all EA games)+Crafting system+Frequent Updates+Easy to learn+Game CommunityTo explain some of those, lets start with "playable."  You can install the game, launch it, and play away.  It works, and you can easily lose a couple of hours right off the bat.  Next, the custom building designer.  Is it perfect: no.  Can you make any building you can imagine: not yet.  But unless you are really trying to build an abstract, strange angled, multi-story building, chances are you can build it.  The crafting system is very nice, particularly the interaction between the crafters.  You start the game with a carpenter.  He/she can make basic furniture, building elements (like doors and windows), and a few other things.  He/she also makes some tools, like a farmers hoe to allow a farmer to be promoted, a mason's chisel for a stoneworker, a weaver's spindle, etc.  Once you promote another Hearthling to a new position, more crafting elements are unlocked.  For example, by him/herself, a carpenter can make a basic bed.  Promote a weaver, spin some thread, and a high leveled carpenter can make a fancy bed, with bonuses for the Hearthlings who sleep in it.The final pro I listed which I want to detail is the game community.  Stonehearth has a fairly active community over on their forums, and everyone there is kind and helpful.  Members on the forum do their best to help each other out, and support is quick.  When I first joined the forum, I was greeted by a moderator after my first post, and recived quick help when I had an issue.  That made me want to spend time there, and as I became more familiar in the game, I started to help people out myself.  The developers are very active on the forums too!  They will help with game issues like crashes, keep you updated on bug fixes, and join in the many discussions about the game and where it should go.  They also stream development sessions 3 times a week, where you get to see work on the game live!Cons:-Bugs, you will encounter bugs!-Crashing can happen-Saves are not always compatible between versions-Game is not feature complete-Can't build everything-Hardware intensiveTo explain the cons: the game has bugs.  If you were not expecting that, I suggest you review what Early Access is.  That being said, the developers are amazingly responsive to fixing them, especially if they are game breaking.  Patches are frequent (sometimes too frequent), and they can break save compatibility.  Fortunately, they have 2 branches of updates on Steam, so if you do not like frequent updates, you can stick to a "stable" branch, and not deal with the frequent develop releases.  Crashing can (and likely will at one point) happen.  Many times it is due to driver issues, but also due to anti-virus programs.  As the games AI is based in an embedded chrome browser, programs that add extensions to chrome can cause havoc.Final con, the game is not feature complete.  You cannot build every possible structure, there are many classes/professions that are not availible, and the game is not fully optimized.  I have played games where Stonehearth has used as much as 9 GB of RAM!  While the usage has dropped significantly in the latest patches, it is still not perfect, and honestly higher than I feel it should be.So, should you buy this game?  I will answer with a qualified Maybe.  If citybuilding, simulation, strategy games are your thing, then this is an awesome game.  If you want a say in how the game is developed, than take the plunge.  If you like being a part of an active community that is passionate about the game, then hop aboard.  However, if you want a bug-free, fully optimized, feature complete game, then this is not for you (yet).  The game is in alpha, features are in active development, but it isn't quite there yet.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
First and foremost you need to understand that Stonehearth is currently in ALPHA. This means there will be bugs, unoptimized code, and a range of other things that appear in alpha level content.Although Stonehearth isn't a revolutionary game, it is still very enjoyable. Even though I’ve only owned the game since Alpha 9, I have spent enough time in the game to get a good feel for the gameplay, features, and overall value of the game. At this point in development I can recommend the game for those looking for a fun game, but aren’t afraid to test out builds, and find bugs. In the games current state your goal is to not kill all your hearthlings. When starting the game you are given virtually nothing to survive other than a tool to make a carpenter and a trapper. From there your job is to craft tools, give hearthlings jobs, and start to grow a tiny civilization. If you are playing on the Peaceful game mode then you really don’t have anything to worry about beyond keeping your hearthlings well fed. The other game mode at this time is Normal, and includes some nice goblins for you to fight with. The goblins don’t make the game overly difficult at this time and really just add another degree of play. Personally I enjoy playing Normal since it can be somewhat boring playing on peaceful mode. As of Alpha 10 the goblins haven’t been in the game very long. They do a nice job of adding more gameplay options though. With the inclusion of goblins you will need to take defense into consideration while building. They will not attack you immediately upon starting a game, but they do increase in difficulty as you grow stronger. One of the strongest points this game has is the robust building mechanic. You can build whatever structures you can imagine, as long as it’s within the boundaries of tiny blocks. The build mode is very simple to use and really help you personalize it to your taste. When you get a structure created you can even save it to use at any time after that. It’s a really nice feature since you don’t have to worry about designing each building every time you need it. The game also allows you to edit the building before placing it, giving you a chance to personalize each one without the need to recreate it from scratch. The only issue I have found when designing the buildings you can’t add in items like desks, beds, chairs, or other things of that nature without having them created and sitting in your stockpile. Luckily you just need 1 on hand to add them into the building blueprint. At this time the hearthlings don’t really have traits, but they do have stats. The stats are things like speed, courage, diligence, etc. and can affect how well a hearthling does his/her given job. As development continues I am sure we will see more stats, traits, and other features added to the individual hearthlings. That is really just a rundown of the main features the game has at this time. If you are interested in learning more about the game feel free to join us over at the Stonehearth.net forums. We always have some discussion going about the game, and keep up with all the little bugs in need of squashing. You can also find my pros/cons breakdown below.   PROS- Music- Art style- Crafting system- Builing/Blueprint system is awesome- Fun factor-Replayability-Great development teamCONS- Occasional building issues- LUA issues(LUA hits 100% causing game to lag and freeze)- Ocassional errors while playing- Lighting/Shadow issues The only con that I’ve found to really be a hindrance is the LUA problem the game runs into. You can see the game resources in real time while playing via a small bar on the bottom right of the game client. Once the LUA usage hits 100% the game will lag completely out. This is a known issue and will hopefully be addressed soon.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
tl;dr Alpha 10 review:Cons:Lot's of bugs, minimal content.  Basically, it's a work in progress alpha game.Pros:Excellent dev team, great mod support, fun game with lots of potential.If you want a polished, feature filled, bug free game then stick StoneHearth in your watch list and wait a bit. If this looks like your kind of game, you want to have input into the development, you don't mind playing a game that will crash on you or just break because you clicked a button that causes an error, and you want to support Team Radiant.  Then buy it now.Full Alpha 10 ReviewIntroWhen you buy an early access game you are not just buying the game, because that isn't ready yet.  You are buying a look into the development of the game and the team behind it, and you get to play along as it's made, and then get the finished product at the end of it.  In my opinion the team at Radiant Entertainment are an amazing developer and I would happily buy into another early access game from them in the future based on my experience with them so far.What started out as a 2 man team when they launched their kickstarter has grown steadily over the past couple of years.  They have always interacted with the community with regular updates on their Dev Blog[stonehearth.net], answering questions, and helping on their Forum[discourse.stonehearth.net], and regular (currently multiple times per week) streaming through Twitch[www.twitch.tv] where they listen to and make changes from live feedback in the chat stream, explain the processes they are going through to help modding, and answer any questions people have for them about the game and it's development.I have total faith that this game will see it's completion and continued support afterwards.The Game (so far)You start with a small band of settlers with limited supplies and tools with the aim of building up a small town.  This is acheived harvesting materials, creating jobs, building items and tools, creating buildings (pre made and custom), and defending yourself from enemies.Controlling your town is a a bit of mix at the moment between telling your Hearthlings (the citizens) to go do something and then being able to forget about it (such as farming), and having to heavily micro manage other aspects (such as controlling production of individual items).  The initial concept from the kickstarter was that you wouldn't have to micro manage things in the town, so I would hope that this will be the case as the game matures.The building aspect of the game is developing well, and has had new features added with each new alpha.  You can choose to use a selection of pre-designed houses/buildings from Radiant or go all out and custom design your own.  The custom buildings part of the game is where I personally have experienced the most game breaking bugs, but it is certainaly getting better all the time.  If this is the part you are most looking at this game for I would hold off for a bit.Each Hearthling can be assigned a job/role within the community and will improve as they perform their tasks.  These include farmers, trappers, craftsmen, and guards.  These all work pretty well, although are all work in progress with the higher end skills still to be implemented.  And there are also new professions being added with each update.  Aplha 11 will be bringing us a cook, no more raw food!Enemies currently come in two varieties; undead, which will spawn on random nights and head to your town; and the goblins which are currently being worked on as part of the campaign that runs in game.  You do have the option to play on peacful mode if you want to build in peace and quite without having to worry about defending yourself.ModdingStoneHearth has been built from the ground up to support modding, and already has several great mods available, adding extra content into the game, changing the themes of the game and more projects in the works.  Because the game supports mods at it's core it is as simple as downloading a mod from the forum and dropping into the games mod folder.Final ThoughtsStoneHearth has a great team behind it, and is showing great potential for being an amazing game.  In it's current state you can definitly get several hours of enjoyment from the game, and get a taster of what is to come.  If you decide to purchase now expect to see bugs every game, from the amusing floating helmets, to annoying error messages, and I would recommend using the pre-made building templates until you are familiar with the rest of the game before venturing into more complex custom buildings.

content:
er 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I kickstarted Stonehearth and have been playing it since it was very, very simple in nature.  The graphics have remained beautiful (if you like voxels) throughout, each iteration has led to massive improvements in gameplay, and a number of bugs have been fixed - and the game is still in alpha.One of the "big deals" about this game is that it takes the dwarf fortress approach to items in the world and materials.  It then layers LUA scripting and html (no joke) for the interface.  Its modding system isn't a modding system so much a content-delivery system.  You want a new race? Describe some things in JSON and boom.This leads to some very, very awesome potential for BETA once all the systems are fleshed out.  The latest update added the second Kingdom, and playing as it evolves into a completely different playstyle.. and as near as I can tell it wasn't much of a code update, just a "mod" from the dev's standpoint.This is working out to be the ultimate kingdom builder / simulator.  Like Dwarf Fortress? You're gonna love this.  Like Minecraft but don't like doing all the digging yourself? You'll love it.  Do you like casual games? Yep.

								I'm writing my review pretty early despite not having much play time so far. I bought this game during the Seam Summer sale at 20% off after having put it on my wishlist a while back. So far, the game is definitely worth the buy- and has shown itself already to be highly replayable even at its current state. I'm writing my review with the understanding that there will be a few bugs, some improvement suggestions, and in mind that more content will be released. Honestly, with where it's at now, I would love for a Workshop to be added for the community. Alas, it's still in alpha...Graphics: 9/10 being pixel themed. Very cute chibi like, so it appealed to me immediately. They glitch out sometimes for me, but I don't find it too annoying to not play. Gameplay Mechanics: 6/10 (this is definitely subject to change) With the fact that as others have stated there is much need for improvement for AI to properly work. I wish that the tasks they did were in order of your selection on what to build- meaning if you choose to build a cottage and you're currently building one- they will flock to the cottage you just qued instead of continuing to build the current one first. A way better tutorial on how to use the game mechanics at this point is highly needed. I had to google with no help to find out how to place a objects, such as my crafting bench, and had to press "P" to finally be able to go to a screen to place objects. After pressing P, I have not needed to do so, and placing objects started working for me. I would have also liked to understand how to use certain classes like the trapper early on. For the first part of your gameplay, you'll probably find yourself very slowly starting to understand how the game works because there is a lack of even a brief tutorial. The only tutorial you get is understanding how the camera options work, which if you play games regularly especially of this type, is pretty self explanotory before you even open the game. Content: 6.5/10* (subject to change) so far there are two playable races and two types of biomes to play in. The races pretty much work best only in their biomes- so if you're wanting to switch it up game play will definitely be harder. Not a bad thing, but I hope to see more races and biomes added for sure in the future which they've shown to be highly likely in the start screen. You are also able to select to be in Sandbox mode, normal, and hard, of course. I hope to definitely see a wider selection of crafting, building types, tasks, enemies, classes, etc. in the future. Once again, it's still in early acess- but even with its options now it's not bad. One complaint I have is that at the beginning of the game, you choose a selection of the map- make sure that the box you pick is not cut off in anyway because that section of the map is the only available area for you to build your village in at least in what I've seen so far. I hope that they change it to where that's just the area of the map that you choose to reside, and still can explore out further. Otherwise, it cuts a huge chunk of game time to me. You can't explore much out of your settlement, and it makes resources limited.Replay Value: 9/10 With the options so far that are available, you still have different scenarios and ways that you can play out in your game. And it's pretty addicting... Reccommend: 10/10 Would reccommend anyone this game at its current state even in early access. Stonehearth has already shown itself to have an extremely promising future. Hope to play with this game as it grows and expands itself. Hope to see DLC and a workshop in the future. :)

								Stonehearth is a fantastic game!!It's cute little city-builder with some strategy and RPG elementsYou establish your own little town, in a randomly generated world Assign classes you your Hearthlings/Villagers. Like footmen, carpender, weaver, farmer. etcDesign your own buildings, draw out the walls and place furniture. content:
1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth has the positives of Dwarf Fortress (DF): a simcity style game that focuses on individual citizens, their lives, attributes, and abilities without the difficult learning curve that makes DF so in-accessible for people. It has beautiful graphics, and has the option for a peaceful setup (for those not interested in fighting).It is by no means complete - but the team has been steadily working on the core functionality - and the improvement shows with each new alpha version. Update:Alpha 17 is quite playable - once you decide to focus on what works rather than what does not  -Lots of content. High quality UI. They have chosen well when they copied Dwarf Fortress (attributes, farming, combat, 3D) and chosen well even, or particularly, when they diverged from it (RPG-type-classes, experience, levels).The game creates interesting decisions - Embark - Race, difficulty level, choice of locationStart - Which classes to focus on, etcWorth buying not just to support but also to play.

content:
r 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've had the game for a while now. It's great, fun, more responsive now given the updates, but the one thing they have yet to fix is the amount the game stutters (even with normal-high FPS (I run the game at an even 55FPS and my Hearthlings stutter like crazy)) at a certain point. You cannot really build too much or queue too much or else your Hearthlings will look like they're making a stop-go walk to their destination (even during work animations). The game isn't bad by any means and a lot of the construction bugs (I.E: not working anymore even when you have all required materials for a building) are squashed. Despite the cuteness and the fact I am recommending this game, I am not currently recommending it until some more optimization is brought into the mix. However, I don't expect my review to cause anyone to wane in their decision (for better or worse) so if you decide to buy it, then by all means you won't regret it if you can get past my aforementioned gripe.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR - Buy it now, You most likely won't be disappointed!A truly excellent game, well worth the money. I've followed the game and development team for 1 1/2 years and they put other Early Access developers to shame. They always keep in contact with us players, and are very transparent (hosting livestreams twice a week - where they show content being developed, and answer questions, and take suggestions/ideas, weekly development blog posts, responding to PMs and threads on the official forums, etc.). When you buy this game expect monthly-ish updates and alongside that pre-release versions to test out. (Very few Early Access games, update this often at all.)The community is also awesome. Check out the official forums where you'll find lots of mods, artwork, animations, Let's Plays,  interesting discussions and very mature and respectable people. I really love this game, and its admirable and impressionable devs. I can tell you right now this is not your typical let-down Early Access game! I can say full-heart'dly to buy this game. It's 100% worth it.Please note though, if you buy this game right now. It's still EARLY ACCESS, and things such as optimization or promised features are not all completed yet. The devs have worked really hard, and I hate seeing people flame the game, while blindly ignoring the fact that it still has a while to go in development. As of now there is plenty of content, and it's fairly replayable. It runs quite smoothly for an Early Access game, too. I say go for it, but if you're picky maybe wait a while! :)[ P.S. - If you buy the game, please watch the weekly livesteams almost every Tuesday and Thursday - and also join the official forums, again really awesome community! :)! ]

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL:DR Do you have a realistic expectation of alpha/early access games? Are you willing to wait for more features and enjoy the current game in the mean time? Do you like the genre of this game?If you ansered yes, this game is for you.I have been playing this game pre-EA release, and honestly believe it is one of the most satisfying kickstarters I have ever backed and is already quite fun to play. It has a brilliant balance of city building, crafting and RPG elements, and rewards the player with a real feeling of progression. Each citizen has their own stats and skills which you can improve and you are able to get very creative with your architecture already with a little effort.PRO- Developer communication, every week there are numerous posts on their websites dev blog covering their progress and frequent developer streams where you may have direct imput in the creation of the game.- The game is being designed to be ULTRA modder friendly, I myself, someone with NO prior experience making mods have already made a few myself without causing bugs in the game in an alpha state. (Expect workshop support)- Frequent updates, the game is beginning to progress rather quickly and is adding features and busting bugs EVERY patch.- A wonderful art style, it maintains a simple charm while still looking brilliant and handling rather well even on less powerful machines.- Balanced progression, the game in this current state is slow enough to last but fast enough to hold your attention.- A fast forward button, I personally find this extremely important for things such as building or mining, or passing time while not active.CON- This is an alpha, there are occasional bugs, especially following new versions, but far fewer than there have been previously. For an alpha I have seen a relatively low amount and they always seem to get fixed before I can encounter them more times but there will be some bugs and if you go in to an early access game not expecting bugs you will be dissapointed.- Villager progression through classes is currently incomplete, quite a few are implemented so far but it does reduce the games variety.- can be hard at times as death of a skilled citizen can set you back for a while.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								To address people raging about this game so far, I’ll repeat what others have already stated. The game is in development, and it will get better. With that in mind I’ve loved this game so far, and it’s been the easiest timesoak game I’ve had for years.This game, in a word is pleasant. I've played games like Banished (which is probably the nearest comparable) where the biggest problem was keeping people alive, and the only way to do so was to go balls out at it deal with problems decades in advance.This, like I've said is pleasant to the point of a city-building game being relaxing. I personally play games to chill out with, and I've always enoyed games within this genre so getting something I can actually chill out with is wonderful.It's easy to understand, easy to progress through and at the time of writing (04/07/15) there are very few problems with it in terms of bugs that I’ve experienced, but I’ll detail any below. I do also have one or two suggestions but I'll detail those at the bottom. (Again, all in development stage. I don’t expect these to be addressed three weeks ago, chill your beans)On the whole though, I've thouroughly enjoyed what these guys have offered already, and I can't wait to see what comes up in the future. It's a solid game as it stands, and it's far from a regretable purchase. -- For the below, I'm just assuming the devs are watching these things -- Bugs I’ve noticedI was able to place single tables within dining tables after building the wrong tables. I don’t know if this is unique but moving things around to get it straightened out was a ballache.SuggestionsThe daily report – while I fully respect people’s desire to blast through games like this. A play through on peaceful mode (for example) where you play at a fairly slow pace leads to a situation where you can’t keep up with the daily goals. If these goals were changed from what seems to be programmed based on what day you’re on, to a flat ‘Achieve this level of food/happiness/net value to get a new person’ the whole thing would flow a lot better.A priority system, or a worker grouping could be set so sorting to storage can be made more efficient. For instance If I can make Phil gather a set range of materials (or if stores are refined enough, just tie workers to those stores). That or create a 'Runner' class of citizen, where their tasks is simply to move things around. (Teamster to the likes of Tropico)

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth, Stonehearth, Stonehearth... Where do I even begin? I absolutely adore this game. I have learned about it some time ago and purchased it via Humble Bundle. Since then, I fell in love with it like never before, as this game is my dream game, one I have always been looking for. It is excellent mix of Strategy, Sandbox and City Simulation. This game, as you can probably tell by the screenshots and movies, have it`s own unique feel and it`s as cuddly and cute as it can get. For now, the game is still in early to mid alpha, so there is much content to add, but even now game can be and is fun to play. Why should you buy this game?  Developers of Stonehearth, team Radiant, are the most amazing team of developers I have ever encountered in my gaming career. You wouldn`t probably believe how much they involve us (the community) onto the process of making game. First of all, they stream on http://twitch.tv three times per week, showing us how the game is being made, also taking countless advices from players (you could affect how the monster will look in game, how some mechanics should work or even name characters yourself). They also let us decide on how the game`s development should go from alpha to alpha (using https://trello.com/b/4XvM0SUd/stonehearth-community-roadmap) so we can choose what content should be made next.  The game have an amazing building system, presented in the trailer. Your little Hearthlings will build everything you can imagine voxel by voxel, using scaffoldings. The building system is very intuitive yet complex, and is being updated even more.  Stonehearth is made in a way that allows players to easily add mods to the game. There already some amazing mods made by community members, and we can expect even more of those coming soon.  If you, like me, always want the game to be as filled with content as possible, you can expect some good things from Stonehearth, In the final version there will be alternative planes, additional biomes, extra races to play as, huge campains to play, dozens of enemies and events randomed by computer Game Master. And much more, that`s for sure.  Last but not least, you don`t have to be afraid of this game being abandoned by developers. They seem so excited about this game, and they don`t slow down while making this game in front of our eyes. I believe it`s a privilege being able to take part of making this awesome game.I r8 8/8 m8.

Early Access Review
								I was looking for a game like Dwarf Fortress but with better graphics and easier to get in to.This is it.Obviously it is not as deep as Dwarf Fortress but the basic mechanics are there.You can build a cute little forest town, or a mountain fortress. You can slaughter all of the pesky Kobolds in the world, or you can be a peaceful little farming village.This game is brilliant. My only problem with it so far, is that you will eat through the Campaign/Story within a few hours.Luckily the replay value so far is in creating new towns etc.Hopefully the devleopers keep up their active content updates and patches until well after the game has gone gold.Couldn't recommend this product enough.

content:
y 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								It is very rare that I log in to make a review. By that I mean (and I don't know if others have this issue) when steam connects me to make one it brings me to a new window where I am not logged in. But that is neither here nor there. Let me begin by saying this game has AMAZING POTENTIAL! However currently the villagers' AI is lacking though it is still an alpha build. Even then the game is still playable though you'll have many of your troopers standing around staring off into the sun like idiots.The great pros to the game:Great potential. Good graphics that aren't hard on your computer (I'm on a laptop, furthermore one built for office work and NOT gaming and I still rarely crash).The ability to build ANYTHING! Yes... anything! You can even build a giant hotdog if you wish.A city builder that isn't annoyingly complicated.The bad:Well, the AI sucks as forementioned. That's a work in progress I hope. Goblin attacks happen very early. I only had a carpenter and I was still working on making a guard when the first attack happened. I lost three of my five villagers. So yes, this is a bad thing but this also hasn't happened every game so perhaps it is just bad luck.Villagers don't seem to really want to work but that's probably just the AI again. Also, there needs to be a method to making each villager assigned to a specific home or shop area. I have farmers sleeping in buildings on the opposite side of town to their fields and blacksmiths sleeping outside the town entirely...

number of helpful: 43 of 73 people (59%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
ry 6
Early Access Review
								Things I like about the game:Fight bossesSurviveManage a settlement and their economy to a pointTemplate or free style building availableExpandMany recipes, more with the t2 items added. Your settlement has jobs. You need certain jobs to open up other ones. Create traps and defend your settlement.Play all jobs at once. Serious time sink and time management for your hearhlings.Gather resources and minePretty gameMusicCute hearthlingsAs they level up they gain better abilities or buffsQuesting availableEntertainingGraphicsJob progessionCareer and ability progression for most employed hearthlingsStoryThings I dislike about the game:In game pop up's of Engine Errors that wipe your game saves or that make it so you can't ever build again on that save or map that you just sunk 50 plus hours into. Been months and no fix for this issue. Happens to others too because my friend who played has the same problem.Slow bug fixes.Building aspect of it is a mess. You can insert windows and doors etc but you have to force trick it to do it to free-style building by placing blocks behind them to connect it just to get a windows since it doesn't really allow for that. You can just use their walls but they are gigantic. Their huge walls have automatic colums and sometimes there is no color match up leaving you on huge builds with ugly colums in odd colors. Limitted colors to build in. Almost no different textures. Lots of solid colors that are blue, orange, tan or brown or pink hues.Double doors stick out of one side out of the doorway more than another side. Objects just aren't even. Lack of space even when making tons of vaults. Not enough clay without digging a lot compared to all other resources available to you when mining.Not enough building variety.Hearthlings are just too slow. Crafting times are too slow.Town inventory item limit is too low for a game that you can build on and decorate as well.Roofing tool doesn't like to work most times.Changing between colors on a wall means you have to select each wall. You can't just apply it with an option to all walls if you wanted too. Making the game even slower.You can't use the delete erase tool for anything other than slabs when building. Making this far more frustrating when building. You can't use it on doors, windows etc either.I lasted a good while on the game but enough is enough. I don't want to keep starting maps over any more. I can over-look many of these things in early access, however I can not over look their Engine Errors that ruining your hours and hours of maps when you can't no longer build on them due to these annoying errors as it breaks players game save files making it so they can't play or progress further. I played it a lot and re-started countless maps from scratch until finally I got burnt out of starting over. Game is slow paced some what as a result of starting over maps. Will update this once this game functions properly for the better & then re-visit it once bug fixes are made to the engine error issues. Follow it if you want. I can't recommend it in this state until they deliver those fixes. Disapointing to do so much work on it, then you have to be forced to start over again.

content:
er 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Hey!This is my first review, so don't expect too much of it.________________________________________________________________________________(Personal Opinion)I can understand that some people don't like it because of its huge amount of bugs and that it has been in Alpha for an extremely long time. But honestly, if you ignore the countless bugs (which will be fixed) the game is one of the best games I've ever played. This game is a place where you could relax, a place where you can be happy without worries.  It helps me get through hard periods where you feel like life sucks. That's because of the music.The music, made by Raj Mann, here is just amazing (google up Stonehearth OST if you don't believe me, my favorite is 'Sailing into the black clouds & blue skies)  and everything, the animations, world, design style is just incredible to look at.The animals and the hearthlings are soo cute to look at.One of the main reasons why I bought this is because of its amazing soundtracks (Mentioned above)but also because of its simplistic playstyle. The AI is a bit buggy, and there are A LOT of bugs that need to be fixed (Its Alpha) but I do believe that this won't be a game that'll be abandoned, because the progress that has been done is immense and the team is just so amazing. Posting weekly blogs about how the progress is going.The gameplay is nice, and you can do a lot of things in the game.Want a big army with only archers and kill all the orcs that appear in random events, here you go!Want to build a palace? Say no more!You can make a big town with all the possible jobs, fully surounded by walls.Sometimes a big army of orcs will appear, trying to kill every hearthling you got and raze the lovely town you got.Or sometimes nothing will happen, and you can be free of worries.TL;DR====================================================================================+Amazing music                                                      I - Still in Alpha+Relaxing                                                                 I - Some bugs+Nice art style                                                         I - Computer heavy (Slow fps if you progress in the game)+Different playstyles (A lot of choices)                  I - A bit on the expensive side+Easy to understand the mechanics                      I====================================================================================Should you buy it? [] YES                               [] DEFINELLY             (That's a Gravity Falls reference btw)                               [] ABSOLUTLYNo but seriously, you really should buy it. You can wait till it is on sale or when its fully released,but its absolutly worth the 23 Euros.That concludes my review. Have an incredible day!

ry 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am quite a big fan of the genre, and have enjoyed related titles a lot. Stonehearth has everything it needs to fill the  form:- Villagers with names and faces (...and stats and opinions!)- Random maps (...and varying biomes)- Crafting / industry (...and leveling craftsmen)- Resource management (...and storage management)- Trade (...and trade missions/events)- Town defense (...and giant zombies).But it doesn't stop at that, the best thing about this game is that it oozes love. It's being crafted with TONS of love. The devs really care for this product, and it shows. It even inspired me to write them a small letter, to which they kindly replied.That said, Stonehearth still has a long way to go until it's a solid, solid release, but I am extremely optimistic about the outcome and wish both develolpers and early adopters the best of luck.

content:
y 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								For an alpha game this has a ton of promise. I am still very excited that the devs for this game are really behind this and whenever there is an issue its fix ASAP, not something you can get for most other games these days. It is simple to learn and allows you to be very creative in your builds. You control your town and your hearthlings and the outcome of the game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves to build and control a town of people. Even if you don't normally like this kind of game or if you get bored with them, this one adds other clans to make it a bit more challenging. Of course if you want a calm game there is a mode for that too! Hell you can even choose what kind of people to start with and have a completely different experience playing all over again. I got this game on the steam sale but even then I would have paid full price for this. A game where the Devs are actually working on the game still AND interacting with the community make this a great game so far and I would buy it again if I had to. Just remember it is still a work in progress, but that does not mean its not worth it as it is right now.

number of helpful: 31 of 51 people (61%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
1
Early Access Review
								Alpha 21 Review:I backed this game on kick starter (2012) because it looked like a neat take on dwarf fortress or towns.  The cute little 3d voxel guys with destructable 3d voxel terrain and customizable voxel 3d buildings and forts, I was sold.  I have played the Alpha on and off for years, and I have waited patiently for a working voxel based town simulator that allows me to create neat buildings with little 3d voxels.  So here is my review, because the game should have been finished back in 2014, according to the kick starter page.Is it like Dwarf Fortress?  -No.  You have much more control over your people in SH, and you only get 20 people...Is it like Gnomoria? -No.  Gnomoria is closer to DF, and SH is nowhere near the oh crap feeling of running out of food and everyone dies.Is it like Towns? -Similar, but watered down.  Less jobs, promoting is painfully slow and the level up system is annoying.  SH doesn't have the dungeon diving that Towns has.  SH more or less keeps you on the surface and you are raided just about every day by very annoying enemies.  Dang near have to keep an army on hand to repel attackers, or build a giant wall around your settlement with a simple door...yes, a door, keeps enemies out.  The devs haven't added the ability for AI to bash or bipass doors in..years.Pros: It's cute, stable enough on common alpha builds to play for a time with little to no serious issues, save the occasional CTD, annoying debug error popups, or the dreaded slowing down of the game when you have 20 peasants all moving around.  Though I have a good rig, so it isn't too bad.  The building of towns or forts can be fun, but it's also tedious and frustrating at times.Some things have improved, like AI path finding, which was terrible in early alpha versions, UI / presentation, stability, and overall performance, which used to be terrible but isn't too bad until late game.  However, many other key aspects of the game have actually gotten WORSE over the course of development.  Primarily, the very feature that got me to back it in the first place, designing and building custom buildings.  CONS:This is one of the few titles that has seemed to go one step forward, and two steps back.  What's more, the developer continuously makes excuses and dumps money in useless quests, presentation, and blatantly feminist artwork.  Most every picture features a woman being in the position of authority or strength and the male is subservient, but that's just personal taste, I don't appreciate feminism or cultural marxism in my games, and feel with the times, it's necessary to warn people that do not want to support such things, or support it, your choice.I was furious when one of the Cannon brothers made the comment to me that not everyone agrees that the editor is a key feature, so it isn't a priority, back in 2014.  Yet over the years, I have seen hundreds of people complain about the editor's bugs and features being removed, not fixed, from the game.  Many of the original promised goals have yet to be implemented in the game, which has been in development for over 5 years now.  With each new Alpha build, a few new tweaks are added, but nothing mind boggling, or remotely close to what was promised ever surfaces.  Like multiplayer, seasons, or a building editor that allows you to modify completed structures or delete walls.Funny that you used to be able to disassemble houses, even re-design houses or erase features.  The feature was bugged, like workers get stuck, are unable to get all the blocks, or AI can't pathfind and the project sits idle and is ignored.  Instead of fixing these things, it was just scrapped in order to add cool things (sarcasm) like, leveling up your workers, constantly being wiped out by hordes of annoying goblins on day four, or re-arranging the UI for the 18,000th time. Come to think of it, I still haven't received my kick starter backer pet reward.Overall, this game could have been really really awesome.  But progress has been really slow going.  So I will not recommend this game to friends unless I see significant improvement.

content:
31, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a fun little dorflike city builder. As with most of these, you start with 7 people (In this game, they're "hearthlings") and from there, you need to set up for food, shelter, resources, and defense. So far so same, right? The two largest twists on this one are how you can set up the housing (completely planning out a building, instead of either a hole in the wall or a prefab structure), and the animation style. I'm trying to find a good descriptor for the animation style, and I keep coming back to "cute". It's not the word I'm looking for, but it does indeed match, in my opinion. I feel emotionally vested in these hearthlings in a way I don't really get from the likes of Gnomoria, Towns, or even Dwarf Fortress, and I honestly feel it's the way they're animated. When goblins are charging into your town and you see your farmers scatter from their fields and cower, it makes you want to protect them. The victories feel more visceral when your footman is taking a giant stone hammer to the goblins instead of just getting lines of damage text.That is the best way I can really put it right there. If you're looking to just build a town, then there are hundreds of other games that do the same thing. If you want to take care of your citizens, check this one out.

--Playing unstable alpha 18--I have been playing now over 8 hours, that's not much, but I have not encountered any game breaking bugs that some people complaining, only couple minor bugs.The game runs well on my computer, Game play mechanics are good, graphics looks beautiful.I have enjoyed my time with this game and at the moment I think I will play many more hours with this tactical town building/managing game. This IS NOT Minecraft, if want you to search something that this resembles graphically I will say CubeworldWhen you start game first time there will be difficulties to understand what to do if you play this kind of game first time, otherwise just by exploring game and searching what your Heartling's can do will solve many problems. there is no tutorial atm, hopefully we get one somedayAlpha 17 is current stable version, but there is no option to remove building(temporarily suspended).So be careful with that. so do not forget door from you building/house.Minor bugs:1.After Completing building they will start tearing scaffolding's down and sometimes they will forget couple of these in place - solution for this - "CTRL-C"  to open console, click select scaffolding and write console "destroy" and its gone.2.Some times after building they left some hunk of stone or couple block of wood to roof top, this is quite funny, and if you wanna get rid of those, again console, or create ladders to get them.3.Sometimes when you get new heartling she/he will spawn in odd locations and cannot find way to your village. that is annoying, time build ladders again.I have not witnessed it myself, but I have read that when you have complex building you should save game before you start build it, sometimes they dont know how to build it, but this might be out dated warning.After 8hours I will give this game 8/10. (I will updated verdict again when I know  more about this game) I really want to give higher verdict but after 8 hours I cant

content:
r 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though I recommended this game, I wouldn't get it just yet. It's so buggy that it is absolutely unplayable. The developers update it regularly and I have full expectations that it will be one of the greatest city-building games ever made when it is finished. It's essentially Minecraft mixed with Banished. You assign jobs and tasks that need to be done, and your little hearthlings go do it. You don't controll the hearthlings directly, you simply guide them. They can die from combat and starvation, so careful planning and resource management is very important. It's as much a game of strategy as it is creation. The game is currently somewhat limited in the designs you can create based on the terrible AI of your hearthlings and the bad UI. It will get fixed, and when it does, you'll be able to create things on par with Minecraft. All while playing a sandbox citybuilder. When this game is out of the alpha stage, GET IT GET IT GET IT!!!

content:
6, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game could be great. I enjoyed managing my villagers, building mines, collecting resources and defending my tiny village from incoming raiders. But one key element has made me decide to not recommend this game.Designing and building things is a struggle against a ruthless stubborn AI and clunky difficult to use controls.The core of this game is about building things. Houses, towers, mansions, whatever you need to house your hearthlings and keep them happy. Right now this mechanic is broken. The controls are non-intuitive. I'm still unable to find a simple way to edit or delete plans. If I do start construction and finish a house halfway and then realise that I forgot to design a window, door, or anything else, I can't change the plan. Instead I have to delete the plan, dismantle and destroy whatever was actually built and then start over. Trying to destroy partially built homes is another struggle. Hearthlings will destroy the pieces around them leaving no way for them to exit creating floating walls or floors and even after you rescue them they refuse to destroy those floating pieces.Building a city is what this game is supposed to be about. It's an early access game. I understand. But I've been watching this game ever since the kickstarter and the constant complaint has always been about how difficult it is to get custom unique buildings created. It's been a few years and this problem is still around. Before you make a decision on whether or not to purchase ask yourself if it is a problem Radiant even CAN fix.

content:
er 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's hard to evaluate any game that is in Alpha, so please take that into account when reading this:I have played this game for about 20 hours. (kids have put in another 40 and they love it) and I find it it be very well crafted and well thought out.  They really have nailed this so far.  every feature that is currently in the game is well done, and the crafting system, and promotion system is complicated enough to allow for a variety of professions while simple enough to play without spending a long time deciding what your citizens should be doing with their lives.If you think the videos look good, you should for sure try this game out, you won't be dissapointed.My only conern with the game is the roadmap and direction it is going.  What I mean by that is I cant really get a sense from googling this game on the internet or looking though the forums how close this game is to being finished.  In my opinion at "Alpha 19"  it is only about half done.  there is no multiplayer yet, (although I believe that is coming)  and what this game really needs is some "dwarf fortress" or "minecraf" machine building capebility, (using physics, and trap doors and drawbridges and leavers and such to really bring your constructions to life.  I assume that is coming in the future, as it really seems like that is what the game is designed to eventually become.  I am enjoying it so far and am looking forward to seeing where the developers take it.

								Stonehearth is a fantastic game, and if you enjoy sandbox/city building games then I highly recommend it.I may be a little biased as I was one of the backers when it was still in Kickstarter, but even then I felt that Radiant Entertainment had a great take on the genre, and a great culture in regards to their backers and fans.  In watching the game and the team grow, I have not changed my mind.  They have shown consistent and impressive improvements to the game, regular updates on the game and the team, and an active role in the discussions.A few notes on the game itself.  It is still very much a work in progress.  Features are still being developed and released, each one coming with it's share of bugs and quirks.  As should go without saying with any Early Access game, only purchase if you are interested in seeing the game grow, and want the chance to add your voice to the development.  Radiant has done a very good job of adding polish to the game as they went, but their primary focus has been features, the rest of the polish comes later.  That being said, I thoroughly enjoy this game, even in it's unfinished state.  Radiant has built a good base for their game, and I look forward to seeing what they can do with it.-NB

content:
y 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								For all potential buyers:This game is very fun and the art style is really awesome. It's like the best of everything from all the pseudo pixel-graphics titles being released so frequently now. I enjoyed playing this game, for an hour or so. The game has a lot of good concepts, but nothing seems even partially fleshed-out. I understand that it is an early access game, but still. Charging $20 for a a game that you can experience everything in within 4-5 hours of gameplay is criminal, in my opinion. While I was watching some of the video reviews/let's plays, I saw that the characters don't have any sort of customization. They have no outfits, you can't assign them to a bed and decide where each one lives. This is fine with me, but I figured it was a trade-off for a more in-depth crafting system and/or building system. However, I was disappointed to find out that this was NOT the case. The crafting is very surface-level(and extremely annoying to level). The buildings have very little functionality other than to make your villagers do what they already do, better. Overall, the experience was a bit underwhelming. It was too much of a simulator(and not even a good simulator at that) and not enough of an interactive city-builder, like I thought it would be. I actually bought this game because I played Cities: Skylines and felt that too much based on the simulation and less based around fun, but in the end, this game left with a similar feeling.TLDR: Fun game. Cool art. No depth. Very little content. If I could reccomend a couple things to the developers: -Add more character customization. Instead of trying to build more into the "job tree", give each person with that profession a separate talent tree that gives each character some identity and gives you a reason to have more than one of them other than just that their job isn't being taken care of. -Add more functionality to buildings.-Increase villager cap and allow for more space to build on and allow towns to be converted into cities. -Add more tutorial information. Almost all of the stuff I had to learn how to do, was learned via videos. The tutorials taught me very little about how to play the game.P.S. I will be keeping an eye on this game with high hopes that it will be improved in future.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								On its way to becoming a great game, but what game that is exactly remains to be seen.What's in the game now, is playable and fun, but also fairly bare-bones.  A lot of essential features are still missing. Being unable to tear down anything you've built being the big one. But there is a solid foundation and a lot of promise for the future and the devs are great at instilling confidence that they'll get there.Currently the game seems a bit torn between macro and micro management. The devs are constantly struggling with how much they want the game to "play itself". You can quickly and easily design custom buildings or plop down existing ones from templates. Farms are plotted out and then self-sufficient. But then you have to go in and tell your carpenter exactly how many beds, doors, chairs, fense posts, etc to make for the buildings you're planning.  Most of the game so far is "set and forget" but then you have to keep a close eye on your crafters to keep them producing what you need.  I could do without that part myself. I'd rather be the city planner than micro-manage the supply chain.Combat is very basic right now. You have guards you can make better gear for, and set areas to patrol or attack but you have no direct control over them. It's more about "were you prepared ahead of time" than skill or micro-management.  This approach could work I think but there needs to be a lot more to it. Hopefully new additions like ranged combat that are being worked on will do just that.  If not, I think they might do well to have combat be the one area they allow micro management to play a key role in player engagement.One thing is for sure, Team Radiant is handling the game's development very well. Communication is definitely one of their strong points. The community is always in the loop and updates are consistent and substantial. Bugs are common but generally fixed quickly.  I get the impression development has gone substantially slower than they initially anticipated but their commitment to see it through is rock solid.The game seems destined to be good at the very least, so it's an easy recommendation. It just remains to be seen if Radiant has the design chops and polish in them to make it great.

								Awesome little city builder with a pretty good system for constructing your own buildingsits one of those games that gives your AI villagers decent autonomy, so you dont really have to micromanage them.the devs are active and as time goes on, ive noticed my little noobs can build more complex structures without bailing half-way through the construction.there are still a few minor issues, but two main ones that ive encountered pretty consistently:- its still difficult, if not impossible, to delete a building design once youve started it, and once youve started the design, its there for good. so if you try to design a building in the middle of town, but mess up on like one of the walls, your better off restarting the game from your most recent save. itll be quicker and actually work, rather than trying to undo what youve done. And sometimes scaffolding will remain forever because your little nubs think theyve completed a building when in fact they have not even come close to it. so the design/construction system def still needs some work.- youll start to run into issues once your little village has a couple dozen citizens. everything will start to slow down simply because of the complexity and demand on your little nooblets. that being said, the devs have been great and every update seems to fix a little bit more. my village can last nearly twice as long without me getting fed up with a stuttering population! so yea, id recommend it but only for like $20 max. wait for a sale, unless you want to support an early access game with active devs ;)10/10 critters stuck on the roof

Early Access Review
								I don't think people understand the point of early access.If you wan't a complete bug free game don't buy this.Otherwise, If you like town builders... Well come on in, sit down, shut up and enjoy the ride. HOWEVER...I have been with this game since it's first playable release... wait... sorry since it's second playable, you get it.It is charming, and rewarding. You build up each and every buiding as well as Hearthlings (your villagers) for better or for worse. Each Hearthling can be given a job (Blacksmith, Carpenter, Hunter. ect. ect.) and based on some seemingly random stats, they will preform well or just level really slow.  When you have enough food/shelter/wealth - more villagers will start to join you (I swear they just  appear, no idea where they come from) Yes, they level to. They also die as well... which is why it is important to have someone with a sword handy at all times, otherwise the raiding goblins or night creatures... will end the town abruptly. Merchants, mining, farming all that good stuff with many many more features that will be implimented down the road thanks to their successful kickstarter.Now enough fanboying... is this game really worth the purchase? yes. Is it worth it in it's current stat? Sure, and I would recommend buying it LATER if you don't want to deal with small and some major bugs. But if you really understand what the concept of early access means and you aren't a child with mommy and daddy's credit card, then go ahead! Support the devs and then go to their forums to post any bugs you find! Then we can get through this a bit faster to release.BTW to my friend's reading this... get this, there will be co-op and PvP later.

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								The best description I can give for this game is that it is like Minecraft if you controlled an entire town.This is a fun game at first, but I don't recommend it right now because the game is far too content light for the price they are asking. The devs are also slow to add content to the game, so their support for this game is quesionable give how long this game has been in early access. Also, the UI can be clunky in places and your townsfolk while mining can trap themselves and die. The game tries to notify you when they're about to die, but it's usually too late. I think they should be able to build ladders themselves and get out of the mine without having to send one of your other people over to build a ladder to get them out. Also, your townspeople will literally work themselves to death if ask them to carry something back to your town from too far away. It seems like these people could say something like "I'm not strong enough to that" to prevent accidental deaths or a UI indicator of how far they can go out to carry stuff back without dying. These kind of things are very annoying but you can get new villagers to replace them fairly quickly at least.You can make buildings for your townsfolk, but I don't see a point to it other than you like to build things. There is no weather cycles or seasons yet and the towns folk have no issue with sleeping in beds outdoors and eating outdoors. Buildings take a long time to build and they don't seem to be worth this investment in survival mode. Walls are okay, but monsters tend to bust down your gates rather quickly. The maps are very wide open in places, so the option to build bigger wall sections would be nice.The classes your villagers can become are cool (there's about 10 or so), but there really isn't a lot they can do and many items are there just for cosmetics. Some classes feel much more fleshed out than others currently. I think this feature will be great once it's finished.Still, the game has a lot of charm and I had fun with it while it lasted, but the game in no way feels finished, so buyer beware, it may be a while before this game is done!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 22
Early Access Review
								What if Age of Empires, The Sims, and Minecraft had a baby? Look no farther for the proverbial answer, my dear reader, this is that game. Stonehearth could be easily dismissed among the ocean of voxel sandbox titles. Upon seeing a few screenshots, I had initially confused it with Cube World, a defunct adventure game that died after its foray into early access alpha a few years ago. Games that employ this simplistic art style are a dime a dozen nowadays... however, Cube World this is not. The premise is as follows: make a village and survive against invaders, mine and collect resources, slay bosses, and construct buildings. You are given a starting set of "Hearthlings" (think 'Sims') and can name them, assign them classes based on their strengths, build them homes and view their thoughts through the town journal. Naming them after real people made me feel more invested and attached to them. I'm really excited to see if they'll add more procedural interactivity between Hearthlings in the future because there's a very solid base for a great role playing sim here.From the moment I started making my first village, it was clear that Stonehearth is very different -- for better and for worse. Because there aren't other games quite like this out there, there's somewhat of a learning curve. There are different camera views, zoning tools, a custom building mode, mining/gathering/looting modes, managing classes, placing items... it's all quite confusing and somewhat daunting at first. I think I accidentally skipped the tutorial when changing the game settings to fullscreen (it made me restart the game and the tutorial was nowhere to be found).After becoming mostly aquainted with the systems, I began to appreciate how there are some wicked smart minds working on this game. The custom building tool -- while clearly an alpha product due to general wonkiness and a surprising pechant for not letting you delete misplaced things -- is surprisingly robust. It's pretty clear that their goal is "If you can imagine it, you can build it." It isn't as time consuming as Minecraft to make a fully custom house, as you can lay the floorplans and everything can be queued up for you, and soon enough you'll watch your little Hearthlings get to work building your masterpieces. On the fastest speed setting (which can only be enabled in the settings), it feels like watching a time lapse. Very fun to see them work.In my experience, I'm left believing that the AI runs on magic. I have no idea how they managed to program pathing, gathering, build-queuing this good... all while running quite well on my 6 years old system. Your workers will always be productive getting done the chores and tasks you've set up for them to do. Of course, they'll stop and tend to their needs from time to time (which only includes taking a lunch break and sleeping... we don't have room for lazy slaves in this kingdom).The team have laid out their broad goals for 2017, which sounds refinement heavy. I've been impressed with their progress thus-far, and updates are frequent.If you have interest in this game: stop hesitating. Once it gets multiplayer in 2018 (my prediction based on their roadmap), this game is going to get a serious cult following. Very impressive alpha.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stonehearth is a (very) cute 3D version of town-building games like Dwarf Fortress or Gnomoria, where you must build a thriving settlement whilst fending off invasions and the like. Like Minecraft though, it has the option to play in peaceful mode for those who wish to just focus on the construction side of the game.It should be emphasised that the game IS still in its alpha stages - that means there's only a limited amount of content in it at the moment. To be sure, there's plenty more to come, but this is definitely *early* access. That aside, it's definitely very enjoyable, and the building editor and the like allows for very complex structures to be built already, and a single game can happily last for a few hours before you've reduced the goblins & undead to little more than nuisances.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DRA great Village building game with mechanics similar to Minecraft, Banished and Dwarf Fortress. Well worth the money asked. Developers are HEAVILY involved in development and community relations, along with consistant and crisp graphics.The community of Stonehearth show how amazing this game is, and how much potential the developers have.---------Where do I start on this brilliant game? I've been watching this EA game since Alpha 2, and have finally decided to buy it. There are hundreds of pros and minimal cons. It is well worth the money asked for (you could wait until the summer sales heil gabeN) Or you can spend it right now!Pros:- The DevelopersThe developers are heavily community focused, implenting features people think would suit the game, as well as fixing game breaking bugs that are encountered. They do frequent updates (Around one every few weeks) and keep the community informed with "Desktop Tuesdays" where they show off new features being implented- Beutiful GraphicsI don't often judge a game by it's graphics. But this is an amazing exception. The graphics are smooth, clear, and crisp, it often reminds me of Minecraft (minus the 16 bit textures) due to its simplicity. The graphics are consistent, and don't randomly change with updates.- The CommunityThe community is very well knit, and are welcoming of new players. You can often find them helping new players settle in to the world of Stonehearth, and help solve problems with bug fixes.Cons- CrashesLike most EA games, there are lots of crashes, there are a few crashes here and there, but if you remembered to save, you're in luck, they've recently added an autosave feature, which is absolutely brilliant, to make up for these crashes. They can be often caused by new features (the 64 bit update) - Steep learning curveLike Banished, it's going to take A LOT of tries to hit the ground running, but after learning why and where you went wrong, it gets a lot easier (my current "village" is on 40 hearthlings) and eventually you will end up with a small town.- AIThe AI in this game can be, at times, tedious, often when you mark a place to be deforested, they cut it down, but refuse to transport it to a stockpile (knowing me this will be the problem on my end), but eventually they get around to it.CONCLUSIONI believe that this game has a HUGE potential, and that the developers are prime examples of what should be the norm in the game industry (I'm looking at you EA) The community is one of the huge aspects of this game, there is some mod support, but sadly most are either broken or outdated. This game is well worth the £19 asked, with many features still to come.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								I would like to talk about the development cycle of this game being that it is in early access. I backed the game for $30 USD in April 2013 on Kickstarter, while the project timelines of the original crowd funding were not met, the transparency and progress on the game by the developers at Radiant Entertainment have always been thoroughly communicated.Despite original project timelines not being met, the team has continued to grow and be staffed were needed, which in my opinion demonstrates sound management on the part of team. This is not a pick up and run with your money type of project. Updates are provided consistently and feedback is incorporated via the games blog, forum, trello roadmap, and Tom and Tony's tri-weekly twitch development streams.Radiant Entertainment was founded by evo2k (the fighting game tournament) and shoryuken.com, founders Tony and Tom Cannon, who had years of working at vmware before venturing on this project. Tony Cannon also wrote netcode middleware GGPO, which was a turning point for online play in the fighting game genre.  I backed the game because of their history, these two have remained accountable and have earned the FGCs trust having been a cornerstone of the community.To conclude, the development of this game two years after its successful crowdfunding campaign continues to demonstrate a level of accountability and trust that is among the best of early access games.

ry 13
Early Access Review
								In essence a dumbed down Dwarf Fortress with goals. And, to be fair it does it very well. The progression system in which you have to level up your villagers in order to give them tier 2 jobs keeps you engaged, as does the ability to get goods from traders in order to complete quests.Certainly worth the money but buyer beware! It's early access and alpha. Game is reasonably stable but locking and memory leaks are common. Don't buy unless you're willing to accept these in this unfinished state.Some current bugs are very annoying. Building not getting finish even though you have all the construction elemnets, down in some case 1 single window. Also some quests rely on certain items which you have to buy and traders never have any (or in my case 3 sunflowers when you need 4. And in 15 hours of play no one turns up with the forth!).Overall it'll be a great game when it's out of alpha and patched up.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have preordered and bought into a variety of different early access games, and Stonehearth is the one of the first few where I feel like I got my money's worth, or at least, will. Though there is currently not much content, I have been quite content (see what I did there) with the game's current state and the direction it is going in. The game has a fantastic community and set of developers that are all intent on making this the best it can be.Now, to the actual game:It is a townbuilding game, like dwarf fortress or towns, with combat elements, random scenarios, specialized workers, mining mechanics, and, of course, housebuilding. I must also say that this game can be very relaxing thanks to its laid back theme and fitting music.Because of it's early state, there are a variety of hilarious but also game breaking bugs. If you are easily frustrated by bugs and do not want to deal with bugs, I would recommend waiting until later to get the game.I must also state that this game opened to steam early access on my birthday, so I am only slightly (completely) biased. Nonetheless, it looks like it will grow into a great game!

content:
8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I want to love this game. I want to play it forever and build forever, but I am pretty frustrated overall with the quality. It doesn't seem to be getting any better over time and the same annoying flaws keep popping up. Removing a building almost never works if the workers get other order in the meantime. I'm not sure how the workers decide what work to do when, but their whole scheduling mechanism needs a ton of work. Likewise, if a building recievs orders, especially ones that contradict previous orders, the newer orders should take precidence, such that I won't be constantly stuck with half-complete building that I cannot force workers to finish nor remove...Likewise the whole grid-selection mechanism is clunky and hard to use. I'd like more control over the selection, and maybe be able to edit and confirm it before workers start digging a tunnel straight down and getting themselves stuck.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR1. Open and honest Dev team2. Game is genuinly fun3. Endless possibilities for its finished potential4. Mod support is a thingI have been a supporter of this game since the kickstarter campaign. It has gone through some very rough, very unpolished builds (seeing as this is currently in alpha 11), but the progress is constant. Each update comes in a timely manner and each one is noteworthy. The devs are open and honest about who is doing what and when things are likely to happen. If there is a setback they will tell you. This in of itself is a massive selling point for this game, just look at the mess that is Godus for a comparison. Regarding the game itself, its what I always wanted in a voxel style game; the freedom to create a city/kingdom from the ground up with my own unique band of citizens.Building is fun; you can follow a few set blueprints or make your own from scratch. As the game develops you will eventually be able to make massive castles, but for the current version as of june 2015 multi-story buildings are the new thing.Combat and resource gathering are about what you would expect, but agian this game is in its early stages and will become deeper as builds go on. Some of the stretch goals filled include elemental enemies and several magic using classes of hearthling. It is still in its early stages, but with the team behind it I am confident the potential will be realised. Another commendation to the dev team behind this game is that from the outset they have encouraged modding. In the future I would not be surprised if the modding community embraced this game like they do bethesda games. In closing, its a great game with a great team behind it and its only going to get better as it develops. Grab it now and become part of the community and help the devs out, because you will be hearing about this game in the future, and you will want it then anyway. Happy hearthing.

0, 2015
Early Access Review
								=HEADS UP=Early Access Review. The game is not finished yet but still worth the price.=INFO ABOUT THE REVIEW=1. This review is about my point of view and opinion. [If you disagree on a certain point or want to correct me: Be reasonable or i will ignore your comment.]=REVIEW=First i just have to say how happy i am that this game finally hits Steam. It was on Greenlight for a while and now finally it is on Steam. I have gotten the game before over kickstarter and i am just going to say that i usually dont get things over kickstarter. For me kickstarter was always a big risk and i never wanted to take that risk. But with this game it was completly different. The cute style and the idea behind it made it to something i just wanted to have.The game overall is a normal little Building/Survival Sim. You have a certain amount of Settlers when you begin and start with nothing but a fire and a Townsflag. Over the time you build up your village and go up the steps towards a city. Mining, Smithing, Farming and even Fighting is already included in this and makes the whole experience already alot better than it looks on the pictures, even though they look quite good. (<3)I cannot say how much i love this litte piece of art. This is one of those games where the devs really sit behind their game. And i am not saying this just like that. First before buying the game i had a chat with one of the Devs and i gotta say that i enjoyed it. After buying it i found a bug to submit and it got rid of right away with the next patch that came a few days after the report.This game has a big future. Please whoever reads this: Be part of this future because i am sure that you will love it!
